heading: broadcom plummets in quake's wake
subheading: the semiconductor industry scrambles to recover after taiwan's 7.6 earthquake. most factories are still standing, but production won't resume for days.
author: reuters
text: shares in communications chip maker broadcom corp. fell nearly 5 percent on tuesday after a devastating earthquake in taiwan threw the world semiconductor industry into disarray. broadcom fell us$5.19, or nearly 5 percent, to $104.13 on the nasdaq trading system."one hundred percent of broadcom's stock fall can be attributed to the quake," said one industry analyst who declined to be identified.the island, which is one of the world's largest producers of semiconductors, was rocked by a 7.6 magnitude earthquake early on tuesday, killing more than 1,450 people and injuring 3,750.a spokesman for irvine, california-based broadcom declined to comment on the effect of the earthquake on the company.although it appeared that most semiconductor factories were left standing after the quake, electricity was cut off to many of them and full production was not expected to resume for 3 to 5 days, the analyst said."the key issue is that we've eliminated the worst-case scenario, luckily," he said.taiwan semiconductor manufacturing co., which is a major supplier of chips to broadcom, said an early analysis showed it could lose about 10 percent of this month's wafer production."we are doing everything possible to minimize the impact of this event to our customers," ron norris, the company's senior vice president of worldwide marketing and sales, said in a statement.taiwan semiconductor reported earlier that its buildings, water and power systems, and computer networks all withstood the quake and that all employees were safe and the facilities were operating on stand-by power.copyright
